verses.textEn: Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ, called as an Apostle, separated for the Gospel of God,
verses.textLa: Paulus, servus Iesu Christi, vocatus Apostolus, segregatus in Evangelium Dei,

verses.textEn: which he had promised beforehand, through his Prophets, in the Holy Scriptures,
verses.textLa: quod ante promiserat per Prophetas suos in Scripturis Sanctis

verses.textEn: about his Son, who was made for him from the offspring of David according to the flesh,
verses.textLa: de Filio suo, qui factus est ei ex semine David secundum carnem,

verses.textEn: the Son of God, who was predestined in virtue according to the Spirit of sanctification from the resurrection of the dead, our Lord Jesus Christ,
verses.textLa: qui prædestinatus est Filius Dei in virtute secundum Spiritum sanctificationis ex resurrectione mortuorum Iesu Christi Domini nostri:

verses.textEn: through whom we have received grace and Apostleship, for the sake of his name, for the obedience of faith among all the Gentiles,
verses.textLa: per quem accepimus gratiam, et Apostolatum ad obediendum fidei in omnibus Gentibus pro nomine eius,

verses.textEn: from whom you also have been called by Jesus Christ:
verses.textLa: in quibus estis et vos vocati Iesu Christi:

verses.textEn: To all who are at Rome, the beloved of God, called as saints. Grace to you, and peace, from God our Father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: omnibus qui sunt Romæ, dilectis Dei, vocatis sanctis. Gratia vobis, et pax a Deo Patre nostro, et Domino Iesu Christo.

verses.textEn: Certainly, I give thanks to my God, through Jesus Christ, first for all of you, because your faith is being announced throughout the entire world.
verses.textLa: Primum quidem gratias ago Deo meo per Iesum Christum pro omnibus vobis: quia fides vestra annunciatur in universo mundo.

verses.textEn: For God is my witness, whom I serve in my spirit by the Gospel of his Son, that without ceasing I have kept a remembrance of you
verses.textLa: Testis enim mihi est Deus, cui servio in spiritu meo in Evangelio Filii eius, quod sine intermissione memoriam vestri facio

verses.textEn: always in my prayers, pleading that in some way, at some time, I may have a prosperous journey, within the will of God, to come to you.
verses.textLa: semper in orationibus meis: obsecrans, si quomodo tandem aliquando prosperum iter habeam in voluntate Dei veniendi ad vos.

verses.textEn: For I long to see you, so that I may impart to you a certain spiritual grace to strengthen you,
verses.textLa: Desidero enim videre vos: ut aliquid impertiar vobis gratiæ spiritualis ad confirmandos vos:

verses.textEn: specifically, to be consoled together with you through that which is mutual: your faith and mine.
verses.textLa: id est, simul consolari in vobis per eam, quæ invicem est, fidem vestram, atque meam.

verses.textEn: But I want you to know, brothers, that I have often intended to come to you, (though I have been hindered even to the present time) so that I might obtain some fruit among you also, just as also among the other Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Nolo autem vos ignorare fratres: quia sæpe proposui venire ad vos, (et prohibitus sum usque adhuc) ut aliquem fructum habeam et in vobis, sicut et in ceteris Gentibus.

verses.textEn: To the Greeks and to the uncivilized, to the wise and to the foolish, I am in debt.
verses.textLa: Græcis ac barbaris, sapientibus, et insipientibus debitor sum:

verses.textEn: So within me there is a prompting to evangelize to you also who are at Rome.
verses.textLa: ita (quod in me) promptum est et vobis, qui Romæ estis, evangelizare.

verses.textEn: For I am not ashamed of the Gospel. For it is the power of God unto salvation for all believers, the Jew first, and the Greek.
verses.textLa: Non enim erubesco Evangelium. Virtus enim Dei est in salutem omni credenti, Iudæo primum, et Græco.

verses.textEn: For the justice of God is revealed within it, by faith unto faith, just as it was written: “For the just one lives by faith.”
verses.textLa: Iustitia enim Dei in eo revelatur ex fide in fidem: sicut scriptum est: Iustus autem ex fide vivit.

verses.textEn: For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven over every impiety and injustice among those men who fend off the truth of God with injustice.
verses.textLa: Revelatur enim ira Dei de cælo super omnem impietatem, et iniustitiam hominum eorum, qui veritatem Dei in iniustitia detinent:

verses.textEn: For what is known about God is manifest in them. For God has manifested it to them.
verses.textLa: quia quod notum est Dei, manifestum est in illis. Deus enim illis manifestavit.

verses.textEn: For unseen things about him have been made conspicuous, since the creation of the world, being understood by the things that were made; likewise his everlasting virtue and divinity, so much so that they have no excuse.
verses.textLa: Invisibilia enim ipsius, a creatura mundi, per ea quæ facta sunt, intellecta, conspiciuntur: sempiterna quoque eius virtus, et divinitas: ita ut sint inexcusabiles.

verses.textEn: For although they had known God, they did not glorify God, nor give thanks. Instead, they became weakened in their thoughts, and their foolish heart was obscured.
verses.textLa: Quia cum cognovissent Deum, non sicut Deum glorificaverunt, aut gratias egerunt: sed evanuerunt in cogitationibus suis, et obscuratum est insipiens cor eorum:

verses.textEn: For, while proclaiming themselves to be wise, they became foolish.
verses.textLa: dicentes enim se esse sapientes, stulti facti sunt.

verses.textEn: And they exchanged the glory of the incorruptible God for the likeness of an image of corruptible man, and of flying things, and of four-legged beasts, and of serpents.
verses.textLa: Et mutaverunt gloriam incorruptibilis Dei in similitudinem imaginis corruptibilis hominis, et volucrum, et quadrupedum, et serpentium.

verses.textEn: For this reason, God handed them over to the desires of their own heart for impurity, so that they afflicted their own bodies with indignities among themselves.
verses.textLa: Propter quod tradidit illos Deus in desideria cordis eorum, in immunditiam: ut contumeliis afficiant corpora sua in semetipsis:

verses.textEn: And they exchanged the truth of God for a lie. And they worshipped and served the creature, rather than the Creator, who is blessed for all eternity. Amen.
verses.textLa: qui commutaverunt veritatem Dei in mendacium: et coluerunt, et servierunt creaturæ potius quam Creatori, qui est benedictus in sæcula. Amen.

verses.textEn: Because of this, God handed them over to shameful passions. For example, their females have exchanged the natural use of the body for a use which is against nature.
verses.textLa: Propterea tradidit illos Deus in passiones ignominiæ. Nam feminæ eorum immutaverunt naturalem usum in eum usum, qui est contra naturam.
verses.notes: The term ‘naturalem usum’ is a way of referring discreetly to natural sexual relations. The word ‘naturalem’ refers to what is natural, but it is also used to refer to the body, or even specifically to the genitals. The earlier reference to ‘shameful passions’ provides a context indicating that ‘naturalem’ does not merely refer to what is natural in general, but specifically to the natural use of the genitals, that is, to natural sexual intercourse.

verses.textEn: And similarly, the males also, abandoning the natural use of females, have burned in their desires for one another: males doing with males what is disgraceful, and receiving within themselves the recompense that necessarily results from their error.
verses.textLa: Similiter autem et masculi, relicto naturali usu feminæ, exarserunt in desideriis suis in invicem, masculi in masculos turpitudinem operantes, et mercedem, quam oportuit, erroris sui in semetipsis recipientes.

verses.textEn: And since they did not prove to have God by knowledge, God handed them over to a morally depraved way of thinking, so that they might do those things which are not fitting:
verses.textLa: Et sicut non probaverunt Deum habere in notitia: tradidit illos Deus in reprobum sensum: ut faciant ea, quæ non conveniunt,

verses.textEn: having been completely filled with all iniquity, malice, fornication, avarice, wickedness; full of envy, murder, contention, deceit, spite, gossiping;
verses.textLa: repletos omni iniquitate, malitia, fornicatione, avaritia, nequitia, plenos invidia, homicidio, contentione, dolo, malignitate, susurrones,

verses.textEn: slanderous, hateful toward God, abusive, arrogant, self-exalting, devisers of evil, disobedient to parents,
verses.textLa: detractores, Deo odibiles, contumeliosos, superbos, elatos, inventores malorum, parentibus non obedientes,

verses.textEn: foolish, disorderly; without affection, without fidelity, without mercy.
verses.textLa: insipientes, incompositos, sine affectione, absque fœdere, sine misericordia.

verses.textEn: And these, though they had known the justice of God, did not understand that those who act in such a manner are deserving of death, and not only those who do these things, but also those who consent to what is done.
verses.textLa: Qui cum iustitiam Dei cognovissent, non intellexerunt quoniam qui talia agunt, digni sunt morte: et non solum qui ea faciunt, sed etiam qui consentiunt facientibus.

verses.textEn: For this reason, O man, each one of you who judges is inexcusable. For by that which you judge another, you condemn yourself. For you do the same things that you judge.
verses.textLa: Propter quod inexcusabilis es o homo omnis, qui iudicas. In quo enim iudicas alterum, teipsum condemnas: eadem enim agis quæ iudicas.

verses.textEn: For we know that the judgment of God is in accord with truth against those who do such things.
verses.textLa: Scimus enim quoniam iudicium Dei est secundum veritatem in eos, qui talia agunt.

verses.textEn: But, O man, when you judge those who do such things as you yourself also do, do you think that you will escape the judgment of God?
verses.textLa: Existimas autem hoc o homo, qui iudicas eos, qui talia agunt, et facis ea, quia tu effugies iudicium Dei?

verses.textEn: Or do you despise the riches of his goodness and patience and forbearance? Do you not know that the kindness of God is calling you to repentance?
verses.textLa: An divitias bonitatis eius, et patientiæ, et longanimitatis contemnis? Ignoras quoniam benignitas Dei ad pœnitentiam te adducit?

verses.textEn: But in accord with your hard and impenitent heart, you store up wrath for yourself, unto the day of wrath and of revelation by the just judgment of God.
verses.textLa: Secundum autem duritiam tuam, et impœnitens cor, thesaurizas tibi iram in die iræ, et revelationis iusti iudicii Dei,

verses.textEn: For he will render to each one according to his works:
verses.textLa: qui reddet unicuique secundum opera eius:

verses.textEn: To those who, in accord with patient good works, seek glory and honor and incorruption, certainly, he will render eternal life.
verses.textLa: iis quidem, qui secundum patientiam boni operis, gloriam, et honorem, et incorruptionem quærunt, vitam æternam:

verses.textEn: But to those who are contentious and who do not acquiesce to the truth, but instead trust in iniquity, he will render wrath and indignation.
verses.textLa: iis autem, qui sunt ex contentione, et qui non acquiescunt veritati, credunt autem iniquitati, ira, et indignatio.

verses.textEn: Tribulation and anguish are upon every soul of man that works evil: the Jew first, and also the Greek.
verses.textLa: Tribulatio, et angustia in omnem animam hominis operantis malum, Iudæi primum, et Græci:

verses.textEn: But glory and honor and peace are for all who do what is good: the Jew first, and also the Greek.
verses.textLa: gloria autem, et honor, et pax omni operanti bonum, Iudæo primum, et Græco:

verses.textEn: For there is no favoritism with God.
verses.textLa: non enim est acceptio personarum apud Deum.

verses.textEn: For whoever had sinned without the law, will perish without the law. And whoever had sinned in the law, will be judged by the law.
verses.textLa: Quicumque enim sine lege peccaverunt, sine lege peribunt: et quicumque in lege peccaverunt, per legem iudicabuntur.

verses.textEn: For it is not the hearers of the law who are just before God, but rather it is the doers of the law who shall be justified.
verses.textLa: Non enim auditores legis iusti sunt apud Deum, sed factores legis iustificabuntur.

verses.textEn: For when the Gentiles, who do not have the law, do by nature those things which are of the law, such persons, not having the law, are a law unto themselves.
verses.textLa: Cum autem Gentes, quæ legem non habent, naturaliter ea, quæ legis sunt, faciunt, eiusmodi legem non habentes, ipsi sibi sunt lex:
verses.notes: This verse and passage is the basis for Church teaching on natural law.

verses.textEn: For they reveal the work of the law written in their hearts, while their conscience renders testimony about them, and their thoughts within themselves also accuse or even defend them,
verses.textLa: qui ostendunt opus legis scriptum in cordibus suis, testimonium reddente illis conscientia ipsorum, et inter se invicem cogitationibus accusantibus, aut etiam defendentibus,

verses.textEn: unto the day when God shall judge the hidden things of men, through Jesus Christ, according to my Gospel.
verses.textLa: in die, cum iudicabit Deus occulta hominum, secundum Evangelium meum per Iesum Christum.

verses.textEn: But if you are called by name a Jew, and you rest upon the law, and you find glory in God,
verses.textLa: Si autem tu Iudæus cognominaris, et requiescis in lege, et gloriaris in Deo,

verses.textEn: and you have known his will, and you demonstrate the more useful things, having been instructed by the law:
verses.textLa: et nosti voluntatem eius, et probas utiliora, instructus per legem,

verses.textEn: you become confident within yourself that you are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness,
verses.textLa: confidis teipsum esse ducem cæcorum, lumen eorum, qui in tenebris sunt,

verses.textEn: an instructor to the foolish, a teacher to children, because you have a type of knowledge and truth in the law.
verses.textLa: eruditorem insipientium, magistrum infantium, habentem formam scientiæ, et veritatis in lege.

verses.textEn: As a result, you teach others, but you do not teach yourself. You preach that men should not steal, but you yourself steal.
verses.textLa: Qui ergo alium doces, teipsum non doces: qui prædicas non furandum, furaris:

verses.textEn: You speak against adultery, but you commit adultery. You abominate idols, but you commit sacrilege.
verses.textLa: qui dicis non mœchandum, mœcharis: qui abominaris idola, sacrilegium facis:

verses.textEn: You would glory in the law, but through a betrayal of the law you dishonor God.
verses.textLa: qui in lege gloriaris, per prævaricationem legis Deum inhonoras.

verses.textEn: (For because of you the name of God is being blasphemed among the Gentiles, just as it was written.)
verses.textLa: (Nomen enim Dei per vos blasphematur inter Gentes, sicut scriptum est.)

verses.textEn: Certainly, circumcision is beneficial, if you observe the law. But if you are a betrayer of the law, your circumcision becomes uncircumcision.
verses.textLa: Circumcisio quidem prodest, si legem observes: si autem prævaricator legis sis, circumcisio tua præputium facta est.

verses.textEn: And so, if the uncircumcised keep the justices of the law, shall not this lack of circumcision be counted as circumcision?
verses.textLa: Si igitur præputium iustitias legis custodiat: nonne præputium illius in circumcisionem reputabitur?

verses.textEn: And that which is by nature uncircumcised, if it fulfills the law, should it not judge you, who by the letter and by circumcision are a betrayer of the law?
verses.textLa: Et iudicabit id, quod ex natura est præputium, legem consummans, te, qui per litteram, et circumcisionem prævaricator legis es?
verses.notes: In the Latin this verse and the previous verse are one sentence, or at least one continuous thought, so that the word nonne of verse 26 applies also to this verse.

verses.textEn: For a Jew is not he who seems so outwardly. Neither is circumcision that which seems so outwardly, in the flesh.
verses.textLa: Non enim qui in manifesto, Iudæus est: neque quæ in manifesto, in carne, est circumcisio:

verses.textEn: But a Jew is he who is so inwardly. And circumcision of the heart is in the spirit, not in the letter. For its praise is not of men, but of God.
verses.textLa: sed qui in abscondito, Iudæus est: et circumcisio cordis in spiritu, non littera: cuius laus non ex hominibus, sed ex Deo est.

verses.textEn: So then, what more is the Jew, or what is the usefulness of circumcision?
verses.textLa: Quid ergo amplius Iudæo est? Aut quæ utilitas circumcisionis?

verses.textEn: Much in every way: First of all, certainly, because the eloquence of God was entrusted to them.
verses.textLa: Multum per omnem modum. Primum quidem quia credita sunt illis eloquia Dei.

verses.textEn: But what if some of them have not believed? Shall their unbelief nullify the faith of God? Let it not be so!
verses.textLa: Quid enim si quidam illorum non crediderunt? Numquid incredulitas illorum fidem Dei evacuabit? Absit.
verses.notes: Literally, ‘absit’ means ‘let it be away’ or ‘may it be far.’ More loosely translated: ‘God forbid’ or ‘Certainly not’ or ‘By no means.’

verses.textEn: For God is truthful, but every man is deceitful; just as it was written: “Therefore, you are justified in your words, and you will prevail when you give judgment.”
verses.textLa: Est autem Deus verax: omnis autem homo mendax, sicut scriptum est: Ut iustificeris in sermonibus tuis: et vincas cum iudicaris.

verses.textEn: But if even our injustice points to the justice of God, what shall we say? Could God be unfair for inflicting wrath?
verses.textLa: Si autem iniquitas nostra iustitiam Dei commendat, quid dicemus? Numquid iniquus est Deus, qui infert iram?

verses.textEn: (I am speaking in human terms.) Let it not be so! Otherwise, how would God judge this world?
verses.textLa: (Secundum hominem dico.) Absit. Alioquin quomodo iudicabit Deus hunc mundum?

verses.textEn: For if the truth of God has abounded, through my falseness, unto his glory, why should I still be judged as such a sinner?
verses.textLa: Si enim veritas Dei in meo mendacio abundavit in gloriam ipsius: quid adhuc et ego tamquam peccator iudicor?

verses.textEn: And should we not do evil, so that good may result? For so we have been slandered, and so some have claimed we said; their condemnation is just.
verses.textLa: Et non (sicut blasphemamur, et sicut aiunt quidam nos dicere) faciamus mala ut veniant bona: quorum damnatio iusta est.

verses.textEn: What is next? Should we try to excel ahead of them? By no means! For we have accused all Jews and Greeks to be under sin,
verses.textLa: Quid ergo? Præcellimus eos? Nequaquam. Causati enim sumus Iudæos, et Græcos omnes sub peccato esse,

verses.textEn: just as it was written: “There is no one who is just.
verses.textLa: sicut scriptum est: Quia non est iustus quisquam:

verses.textEn: There is no one who understands. There is no one who seeks God.
verses.textLa: non est intelligens, non est requirens Deum.

verses.textEn: All have gone astray; together they have become useless. There is no one who does good; there is not even one.
verses.textLa: Omnes declinaverunt, simul inutiles facti sunt, non est qui faciat bonum, non est usque ad unum.

verses.textEn: Their throat is an open sepulcher. With their tongues, they have been acting deceitfully. The venom of asps is under their lips.
verses.textLa: Sepulchrum patens est guttur eorum, linguis suis dolose agebant: Venenum aspidum sub labiis eorum:

verses.textEn: Their mouth is full of curses and bitterness.
verses.textLa: Quorum os maledictione, et amaritudine plenum est:

verses.textEn: Their feet are swift to shed blood.
verses.textLa: Veloces pedes eorum ad effundendum sanguinem:

verses.textEn: Grief and unhappiness are in their ways.
verses.textLa: Contritio, et infelicitas in viis eorum:

verses.textEn: And the way of peace they have not known.
verses.textLa: et viam pacis non cognoverunt:

verses.textEn: There is no fear of God before their eyes.”
verses.textLa: Non est timor Dei ante oculos eorum.

verses.textEn: But we know that whatever the law speaks, it speaks to those who are in the law, so that every mouth may be silenced and the entire world may be subject to God.
verses.textLa: Scimus autem quoniam quæcumque lex loquitur, iis, qui in lege sunt, loquitur: ut omne os obstruatur, et subditus fiat omnis mundus Deo:

verses.textEn: For in his presence no flesh shall be justified by the works of the law. For knowledge of sin is through the law.
verses.textLa: quia ex operibus legis non iustificabitur omnis caro coram illo. Per legem enim cognitio peccati.

verses.textEn: But now, without the law, the justice of God, to which the law and the prophets have testified, has been made manifest.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem sine lege iustitia Dei manifestata est: testificata a lege et Prophetis.

verses.textEn: And the justice of God, through the faith of Jesus Christ, is in all those and over all those who believe in him. For there is no distinction.
verses.textLa: Iustitia autem Dei per fidem Iesu Christi in omnes, et super omnes, qui credunt in eum: non enim est distinctio:

verses.textEn: For all have sinned and all are in need of the glory of God.
verses.textLa: Omnes enim peccaverunt, et egent gloria Dei.

verses.textEn: We have been justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus,
verses.textLa: Iustificati gratis per gratiam ipsius, per redemptionem, quæ est in Christo Iesu,

verses.textEn: whom God has offered as a propitiation, through faith in his blood, to reveal his justice for the remission of the former offenses,
verses.textLa: quem proposuit Deus propitiationem per fidem in sanguine ipsius, ad ostensionem iustitiæ suæ propter remissionem præcedentium delictorum

verses.textEn: and by the forbearance of God, to reveal his justice in this time, so that he himself might be both the Just One and the Justifier of anyone who is of the faith of Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: in sustentatione Dei, ad ostensionem iustitiæ eius in hoc tempore: ut sit ipse iustus, et iustificans eum, qui est ex fide Iesu Christi.

verses.textEn: So then, where is your self-exaltation? It is excluded. Through what law? That of works? No, but rather through the law of faith.
verses.textLa: Ubi est ergo gloriatio tua? Exclusa est. Per quam legem? Factorum? Non: sed per legem fidei.

verses.textEn: For we judge a man to be justified by faith, without the works of the law.
verses.textLa: Arbitramur enim iustificari hominem per fidem sine operibus legis.

verses.textEn: Is God of the Jews only and not also of the Gentiles? On the contrary, of the Gentiles also.
verses.textLa: An Iudæorum Deus tantum? Nonne et Gentium? Immo et Gentium.

verses.textEn: For One is the God who justifies circumcision by faith and uncircumcision through faith.
verses.textLa: Quoniam quidem unus est Deus, qui iustificat circumcisionem ex fide, et præputium per fidem.

verses.textEn: Are we then destroying the law through faith? Let it not be so! Instead, we are making the law stand.
verses.textLa: Legem ergo destruimus per fidem? Absit: sed legem statuimus.

verses.textEn: So then, what shall we say that Abraham had achieved, who is our father according to the flesh?
verses.textLa: Quid ergo dicemus invenisse Abraham patrem nostrum secundum carnem?

verses.textEn: For if Abraham was justified by works, he would have glory, but not with God.
verses.textLa: Si enim Abraham ex operibus iustificatus est, habet gloriam, sed non apud Deum.

verses.textEn: For what does Scripture say? “Abram believed God, and it was reputed to him unto justice.”
verses.textLa: Quid enim dicit Scriptura? Credidit Abraham Deo: et reputatam est illi ad iustitiam.

verses.textEn: But for he who works, wages are not accounted according to grace, but according to debt.
verses.textLa: Ei autem, qui operatur, merces non imputatur secundum gratiam, sed secundum debitum.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, for he who does not work, but who believes in him who justifies the impious, his faith is reputed unto justice, according to the purpose of the grace of God.
verses.textLa: Ei vero, qui non operatur, credenti autem in eum, qui iustificat impium, reputatur fides eius ad iustitiam secundum propositum gratiæ Dei.

verses.textEn: Similarly, David also declares the blessedness of a man, to whom God brings justice without works:
verses.textLa: Sicut et David dicit beatitudinem hominis, cui Deus accepto fert iustitiam sine operibus:

verses.textEn: “Blessed are they whose iniquities have been forgiven and whose sins have been covered.
verses.textLa: Beati, quorum remissæ sunt iniquitates, et quorum tecta sunt peccata.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man to whom the Lord has not imputed sin.”
verses.textLa: Beatus vir, cui non imputavit Dominus peccatum.

verses.textEn: Does this blessedness, then, remain only in the circumcised, or is it even in the uncircumcised? For we say that faith was reputed to Abraham unto justice.
verses.textLa: Beatitudo ergo hæc in circumcisione tantum manet, an etiam in præputio? Dicimus enim quia reputata est Abrahæ fides ad iustitiam.

verses.textEn: But then how was it reputed? In circumcision or in uncircumcision? Not in circumcision, but in uncircumcision.
verses.textLa: Quomodo ergo reputata est? In circumcisione, an in præputio? Non in circumcisione, sed in præputio.

verses.textEn: For he received the sign of circumcision as a symbol of the justice of that faith which exists apart from circumcision, so that he might be the father of all those who believe while uncircumcised, so that it might also be reputed to them unto justice,
verses.textLa: Et signum accepit circumcisionis, signaculum iustitiæ fidei, quæ est in præputio: ut sit pater omnium credentium per præputium, ut reputetur et illis ad iustitiam:

verses.textEn: and he might be the father of circumcision, not only for those who are of circumcision, but even for those who follow the footsteps of that faith which is in the uncircumcision of our father Abraham.
verses.textLa: et sit pater circumcisionis non iis tantum, qui sunt ex circumcisione, sed et iis, qui sectantur vestigia fidei, quæ est in præputio patris nostri Abrahæ.

verses.textEn: For the Promise to Abraham, and to his posterity, that he would inherit the world, was not through the law, but through the justice of faith.
verses.textLa: Non enim per legem promissio Abrahæ, aut semini eius ut heres esset mundi: sed per iustitiam fidei.

verses.textEn: For if those who are of the law are the heirs, then faith becomes empty and the Promise is abolished.
verses.textLa: Si enim qui ex lege, heredes sunt: exinanita est fides, abolita est promissio.

verses.textEn: For the law works unto wrath. And where there is no law, there is no law-breaking.
verses.textLa: Lex enim iram operatur. Ubi enim non est lex: nec prævaricatio.

verses.textEn: Because of this, it is from faith according to grace that the Promise is ensured for all posterity, not only for those who are of the law, but also for those who are of the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all before God,
verses.textLa: Ideo ex fide, ut secundum gratiam firma sit promissio omni semini, non ei, qui ex lege est solum, sed et ei qui ex fide est Abrahæ, qui pater est omnium nostrum ante Deum,

verses.textEn: in whom he believed, who revives the dead and who calls those things that do not exist into existence. For it is written: “I have established you as the father of many nations.”
verses.textLa: cui credidit, qui vivificat mortuos, et vocat ea quæ non sunt, tamquam ea quæ sunt. (Sicut scriptum est: Quia patrem multarum gentium posui te.)

verses.textEn: And he believed, with a hope beyond hope, so that he might become the father of many nations, according to what was said to him: “So shall your posterity be.”
verses.textLa: Qui contra spem in spem credidit, ut fieret pater multarum gentium secundum quod dictum est ei: Sic erit semen tuum.

verses.textEn: And he was not weakened in faith, nor did he consider his own body to be dead (though he was then almost one hundred years old), nor the womb of Sarah to be dead.
verses.textLa: Et non infirmatus est fide, nec consideravit corpus suum emortuum, cum iam fere centum esset annorum: et emortuam vulvam Saræ:

verses.textEn: And then, in the Promise of God, he did not hesitate out of distrust, but instead he was strengthened in faith, giving glory to God,
verses.textLa: In repromissione etiam Dei non hæsitavit diffidentia, sed confortatus est fide, dans gloriam Deo:

verses.textEn: knowing most fully that whatever God has promised, he is also able to accomplish.
verses.textLa: plenissime sciens quia quæcumque promisit, potens est et facere.

verses.textEn: And for this reason, it was reputed to him unto justice.
verses.textLa: Ideo et reputatum est illi ad iustitiam.

verses.textEn: Now this has been written, that it was reputed to him unto justice, not only for his sake,
verses.textLa: Non est autem scriptum tantum propter ipsum quia reputatum est illi ad iustitiam:

verses.textEn: but also for our sake. For the same shall be reputed to us, if we believe in him who raised up our Lord Jesus Christ from the dead,
verses.textLa: sed et propter nos, quibus reputabitur credentibus in eum, qui suscitavit Iesum Christum Dominum nostrum a mortuis,

verses.textEn: who was handed over because of our offenses, and who rose again for our justification.
verses.textLa: qui traditus est propter delicta nostra, et resurrexit propter iustificationem nostram.

verses.textEn: Therefore, having been justified by faith, let us be at peace with God, through our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: Iustificati ergo ex fide, pacem habeamus ad Deum per Dominum nostrum Iesum Christum:

verses.textEn: For through him we also have access by faith to this grace, in which we stand firm, and to glory, in the hope of the glory of the sons of God.
verses.textLa: per quem et habemus accessum per fidem in gratiam istam, in qua stamus, et gloriamur in spe gloriæ filiorum Dei.

verses.textEn: And not only that, but we also find glory in tribulation, knowing that tribulation exercises patience,
verses.textLa: Non solum autem, sed et gloriamur in tribulationibus: scientes quod tribulatio patientiam operatur:

verses.textEn: and patience leads to proving, yet truly proving leads to hope,
verses.textLa: patientia autem probationem, probatio vero spem,

verses.textEn: but hope is not unfounded, because the love of God is poured forth in our hearts through the Holy Spirit, who has been given to us.
verses.textLa: spes autem non confundit: quia charitas Dei diffusa est in cordibus nostris per Spiritum sanctum, qui datus est nobis.

verses.textEn: Yet why did Christ, while we were still infirm, at the proper time, suffer death for the impious?
verses.textLa: Ut quid enim Christus, cum adhuc infirmi essemus, secundum tempus pro impiis mortuus est?

verses.textEn: Now someone might barely be willing to die for the sake of justice, for example, perhaps someone might dare to die for the sake of a good man.
verses.textLa: Vix enim pro iusto quis moritur: nam pro bono forsitan quis audeat mori.

verses.textEn: But God demonstrates his love for us in that, while we were yet sinners, at the proper time,
verses.textLa: Commendat autem charitatem suam Deus in nobis: quoniam cum adhuc peccatores essemus, secundum tempus,

verses.textEn: Christ died for us. Therefore, having been justified now by his blood, all the more so shall we be saved from wrath through him.
verses.textLa: Christus pro nobis mortuus est: multo igitur magis nunc iustificati in sanguine ipsius, salvi erimus ab ira per ipsum.

verses.textEn: For if we were reconciled to God through the death of his Son, while we were still enemies, all the more so, having been reconciled, shall we be saved by his life.
verses.textLa: Si enim cum inimici essemus, reconciliati sumus Deo per mortem Filii eius: multo magis reconciliati, salvi erimus in vita ipsius.

verses.textEn: And not only that, but we also glory in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received reconciliation.
verses.textLa: Non solum autem: sed et gloriamur in Deo per Dominum nostrum Iesum Christum, per quem nunc reconciliationem accepimus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, just as through one man sin entered into this world, and through sin, death; so also death was transferred to all men, to all who have sinned.
verses.textLa: Propterea sicut per unum hominem peccatum in hunc mundum intravit, et per peccatum mors, et ita in omnes homines mors pertransiit, in quo omnes peccaverunt:

verses.textEn: For even before the law, sin was in the world, but sin was not imputed while the law did not exist.
verses.textLa: Usque ad legem enim peccatum erat in mundo: peccatum autem non imputabatur, cum lex non esset.

verses.textEn: Yet death reigned from Adam until Moses, even in those who have not sinned, in the likeness of the transgression of Adam, who is a figure of him who was to come.
verses.textLa: Sed regnavit mors ab Adam usque ad Moysen etiam in eos, qui non peccaverunt in similitudinem prævaricationis Adæ, qui est forma futuri.

verses.textEn: But the gift is not entirely like the offense. For though by the offense of one, many died, yet much more so, by the grace of one man, Jesus Christ, has the grace and gift of God abounded to many.
verses.textLa: Sed non sicut delictum, ita et donum. Si enim unius delicto multi mortui sunt: multo magis gratia Dei et donum in gratia unius hominis Iesu Christi in plures abundavit.
verses.notes: Literally, this says: ‘But not as the offense, so also the gift.’ A comparison is being made of two things, one of which is like a negative image of the other; their similarities are by way of opposites.

verses.textEn: And the sin through one is not entirely like the gift. For certainly, the judgment of one was unto condemnation, but the grace toward many offenses is unto justification.
verses.textLa: Et non sicut per unum peccatum, ita et donum. Nam iudicium quidem ex uno in condemnationem: gratia autem ex multis delictis in iustificationem.

verses.textEn: For though, by the one offense, death reigned through one, yet so much more so shall those who receive an abundance of grace, both of the gift and of justice, reign in life through the one Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: Si enim unius delicto mors regnavit per unum: multo magis abundantiam gratiæ, et donationis, et iustitiæ accipientes, in vita regnabunt per unum Iesum Christum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, just as through the offense of one, all men fell under condemnation, so also through the justice of one, all men fall under justification unto life.
verses.textLa: Igitur sicut per unius delictum in omnes homines in condemnationem: sic et per unius iustitiam in omnes homines in iustificationem vitæ.

verses.textEn: For, just as through the disobedience of one man, many were established as sinners, so also through the obedience of one man, many shall be established as just.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim per inobedientiam unius hominis, peccatores constituti sunt multi: ita et per unius obeditionem, iusti constituentur multi.

verses.textEn: Now the law entered in such a way that offenses would abound. But where offenses were abundant, grace was superabundant.
verses.textLa: Lex autem subintravit ut abundaret delictum. Ubi autem abundavit delictum, superabundavit gratia.

verses.textEn: So then, just as sin has reigned unto death, so also may grace reign through justice unto eternal life, through Jesus Christ our Lord.
verses.textLa: Ut sicut regnavit peccatum in mortem: ita et gratia regnet per iustitiam in vitam æternam, per Iesum Christum Dominum nostrum.

verses.textEn: So what shall we say? Should we remain in sin, so that grace may abound?
verses.textLa: Quid ergo dicemus? Permanebimus in peccato ut gratia abundet?

verses.textEn: Let it not be so! For how can we who have died to sin still live in sin?
verses.textLa: Absit. Qui enim mortui sumus peccato, quomodo adhuc vivemus in illo?

verses.textEn: Do you not know that those of us who have been baptized in Christ Jesus have been baptized into his death?
verses.textLa: An ignoratis quia quicumque baptizati sumus in Christo Iesu, in morte ipsius baptizati sumus?

verses.textEn: For through baptism we have been buried with him into death, so that, in the manner that Christ rose from the dead, by the glory of the Father, so may we also walk in the newness of life.
verses.textLa: Consepulti enim sumus cum illo per baptismum in mortem: ut quomodo Christus surrexit a mortuis per gloriam Patris, ita et nos in novitate vitæ ambulemus.

verses.textEn: For if we have been planted together, in the likeness of his death, so shall we also be, in the likeness of his resurrection.
verses.textLa: Si enim complantati facti sumus similitudini mortis eius: simul et resurrectionis erimus.

verses.textEn: For we know this: that our former selves have been crucified together with him, so that the body which is of sin may be destroyed, and moreover, so that we may no longer serve sin.
verses.textLa: Hoc scientes, quia vetus homo noster simul crucifixus est, ut destruatur corpus peccati, et ultra non serviamus peccato.

verses.textEn: For he who has died has been justified from sin.
verses.textLa: Qui enim mortuus est, iustificatus est a peccato.

verses.textEn: Now if we have died with Christ, we believe that we shall also live together with Christ.
verses.textLa: Si autem mortui sumus cum Christo: credimus quia simul etiam vivemus cum Christo:

verses.textEn: For we know that Christ, in rising up from the dead, can no longer die: death no longer has dominion over him.
verses.textLa: scientes quod Christus resurgens ex mortuis iam non moritur, mors illi ultra non dominabitur.

verses.textEn: For in as much as he died for sin, he died once. But in as much as he lives, he lives for God.
verses.textLa: Quod enim mortuus est peccato, mortuus est semel: quod autem vivit, vivit Deo.

verses.textEn: And so, you should consider yourselves to be certainly dead to sin, and to be living for God in Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.textLa: Ita et vos existimate, vos mortuos quidem esse peccato, viventes autem Deo, in Christo Iesu Domino nostro.

verses.textEn: Therefore, let not sin reign in your mortal body, such that you would obey its desires.
verses.textLa: Non ergo regnet peccatum in vestro mortali corpore ut obediatis concupiscentiis eius.

verses.textEn: Nor should you offer the parts of your body as instruments of iniquity for sin. Instead, offer yourselves to God, as if you were living after death, and offer the parts of your body as instruments of justice for God.
verses.textLa: Sed neque exhibeatis membra vestra arma iniquitatis peccato: sed exhibete vos Deo, tamquam ex mortuis viventes: et membra vestra arma iustitiæ Deo.

verses.textEn: For sin should not have dominion over you. For you are not under the law, but under grace.
verses.textLa: Peccatum enim vobis non dominabitur: non enim sub lege estis, sed sub gratia.
verses.notes: Enim is used so frequently in these ancient texts partly because ancient writing had no spaces between words and no difference between capital and small letters, and no punctuation. So certain words have the function of punctuation.

verses.textEn: What is next? Should we sin because we are not under the law, but under grace? Let it not be so!
verses.textLa: Quid ergo? Peccabimus, quoniam non sumus sub lege, sed sub gratia? Absit.

verses.textEn: Do you not know to whom you are offering yourselves as servants under obedience? You are the servants of whomever you obey: whether of sin, unto death, or of obedience, unto justice.
verses.textLa: Nescitis quoniam cui exhibetis vos servos ad obediendum, servi estis eius, cui obeditis, sive peccati ad mortem, sive obeditionis ad iustitiam?

verses.textEn: But thanks be to God that, though you used to be the servants of sin, now you have been obedient from the heart to the very form of the doctrine into which you have been received.
verses.textLa: Gratias autem Deo quod fuistis servi peccati, obedistis autem ex corde in eam formam doctrinæ, in quam traditi estis.
verses.notes: The Latin verb ‘traditi estis’ calls to mind the English word ‘tradition’ (or Tradition), but this is lost in translation.

verses.textEn: And having been freed from sin, we have become servants of justice.
verses.textLa: Liberati autem a peccato, servi facti estis iustitiæ.

verses.textEn: I am speaking in human terms because of the infirmity of your flesh. For just as you offered the parts of your body to serve impurity and iniquity, for the sake of iniquity, so also have you now yielded the parts of your body to serve justice, for the sake of sanctification.
verses.textLa: Humanum dico, propter infirmitatem carnis vestræ: sicut enim exhibuistis membra vestra servire immunditiæ, et iniquitati ad iniquitatem, ita nunc exhibete membra vestra servire iustitiæ in santificationem.

verses.textEn: For though you were once the servants of sin, you have become the children of justice.
verses.textLa: Cum enim servi essetis peccati, liberi fuistis iustitiæ.

verses.textEn: But what fruit did you hold at that time, in those things about which you are now ashamed? For the end of those things is death.
verses.textLa: Quem ergo fructum habuistis tunc in illis, in quibus nunc erubescitis? Nam finis illorum mors est.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, having been freed now from sin, and having been made servants of God, you hold your fruit in sanctification, and truly its end is eternal life.
verses.textLa: Nunc vero liberati a peccato, servi autem facti Deo, habetis fructum vestrum in santificationem, finem vero vitam æternam.

verses.textEn: For the wages of sin is death. But the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.textLa: Stipendia enim peccati, mors. Gratia autem Dei, vita æterna, in Christo Iesu Domino nostro.
verses.notes: The translation ‘free gift’ fits the context better than ‘grace,’ because this is a comparison with ‘wages’.

verses.textEn: Or do you not know, brothers, (now I am speaking to those who know the law) that the law has dominion over a man only so long as he lives?
verses.textLa: An ignoratis fratres (scientibus enim legem loquor) quia lex in homine dominatur quanto tempore vivit?

verses.textEn: For example, a woman who is subject to a husband is obligated by the law while her husband lives. But when her husband has died, she is released from the law of her husband.
verses.textLa: Nam quæ sub viro est mulier, vivente viro, alligata est legi: si autem mortuus fuerit vir eius, soluta est a lege viri.

verses.textEn: Therefore, while her husband lives, if she has been with another man, she should be called an adulteress. But when her husband has died, she is freed from the law of her husband, such that, if she has been with another man, she is not an adulteress.
verses.textLa: Igitur, vivente viro, vocabitur adultera si fuerit cum alio viro: si autem mortuus fuerit vir eius, liberata est a lege viri: ut non sit adultera si fuerit cum alio viro.

verses.textEn: And so, my brothers, you also have become dead to the law, through the body of Christ, so that you may be another one who has risen from the dead, in order that we may bear fruit for God.
verses.textLa: Itaque fratres mei et vos mortificati estis legi per corpus Christi: ut sitis alterius, qui ex mortuis resurrexit, ut fructificemus Deo.

verses.textEn: For when we were in the flesh, the passions of sins, which were under the law, operated within our bodies, so as to bear fruit unto death.
verses.textLa: Cum enim essemus in carne, passiones peccatorum, quæ per legem erant, operabantur in membris nostris, ut fructificarent morti.

verses.textEn: But now we have been released from the law of death, by which we were being held, so that now we may serve with a renewed spirit, and not in the old way, by the letter.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem soluti sumus a lege mortis, in qua detinebamur, ita ut serviamus in novitate spiritus, et non in vetustate litteræ.

verses.textEn: What should we say next? Is the law sin? Let it not be so! But I do not know sin, except through the law. For example, I would not have known about coveting, unless the law said: “You shall not covet.”
verses.textLa: Quid ergo dicemus? Lex peccatum est? Absit. Sed peccatum non cognovi, nisi per legem: nam concupiscentiam nesciebam, nisi lex diceret: Non concupisces.

verses.textEn: But sin, receiving an opportunity through the commandment, wrought in me all manner of coveting. For apart from the law, sin was dead.
verses.textLa: Occasione autem accepta, peccatum per mandatum operatum est in me omnem concupiscentiam. Sine lege enim peccatum mortuum erat.

verses.textEn: Now I lived for some time apart from the law. But when the commandment had arrived, sin was revived,
verses.textLa: Ego autem vivebam sine lege aliquando. Sed cum venisset mandatum, peccatum revixit.

verses.textEn: and I died. And the commandment, which was unto life, was itself found to be unto death for me.
verses.textLa: Ego autem mortuus sum: et inventum est mihi mandatum, quod erat ad vitam, hoc esse ad mortem.

verses.textEn: For sin, receiving an opportunity through the commandment, seduced me, and, through the law, sin killed me.
verses.textLa: Nam peccatum occasione accepta per mandatum, seduxit me, et per illud occidit.

verses.textEn: And so, the law itself is indeed holy, and the commandment is holy and just and good.
verses.textLa: Itaque lex quidem sancta, et mandatum sanctum, et iustum, et bonum.

verses.textEn: Then was what is good made into death for me? Let it not be so! But rather sin, in order that it might be known as sin by what is good, wrought death in me; so that sin, through the commandment, might become sinful beyond measure.
verses.textLa: Quod ergo bonum est, mihi factum est mors? Absit. Sed peccatum, ut appareat peccatum, per bonum operatum est mihi mortem: ut fiat supra modum peccans peccatum per mandatum.

verses.textEn: For we know that the law is spiritual. But I am carnal, having been sold under sin.
verses.textLa: Scimus enim quia lex spiritualis est: ego autem carnalis sum venundatus sub peccato.

verses.textEn: For I do things that I do not understand. For I do not do the good that I want to do. But the evil that I hate is what I do.
verses.textLa: Quod enim operor, non intelligo. Non enim quod volo bonum, hoc ago: sed quod odi malum, illud facio.

verses.textEn: So, when I do what I do not want to do, I am in agreement with the law, that the law is good.
verses.textLa: Si autem quod nolo, illud facio: consentio legi, quoniam bona est.

verses.textEn: But I am then acting not according to the law, but according to the sin which lives within me.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem iam non ego operor illud, sed quod habitat in me peccatum.

verses.textEn: For I know that what is good does not live within me, that is, within my flesh. For the willingness to do good lies close to me, but the carrying out of that good, I cannot reach.
verses.textLa: Scio enim quia non habitat in me, hoc est in carne mea, bonum. Nam velle, adiacet mihi: perficere autem bonum, non invenio.
verses.notes: The verb ‘invenio’ does not always mean to find or to discover. It can also refer to an attempt to achieve something, to what one might manage to do.

verses.textEn: For I do not do the good that I want to do. But instead, I do the evil that I do not want to do.
verses.textLa: Non enim quod volo bonum, hoc facio: sed quod nolo malum, hoc ago.

verses.textEn: Now if I do what I am not willing to do, it is no longer I who am doing it, but the sin which lives within me.
verses.textLa: Si autem quod nolo, illud facio: iam non ego operor illud, sed quod habitat in me, peccatum.

verses.textEn: And so, I discover the law, by wanting to do good within myself, though evil lies close beside me.
verses.textLa: Invenio igitur legem, volenti mihi facere bonum, quoniam mihi malum adiacet:

verses.textEn: For I am delighted with the law of God, according to the inner man.
verses.textLa: condelector enim legi Dei secundum interiorem hominem:

verses.textEn: But I perceive another law within my body, fighting against the law of my mind, and captivating me with the law of sin which is in my body.
verses.textLa: video autem aliam legem in membris meis, repugnantem legi mentis meæ, et captivantem me in lege peccati, quæ est in membris meis.

verses.textEn: Unhappy man that I am, who will free me from this body of death?
verses.textLa: Infelix ego homo, quis me liberabit de corpore mortis huius?

verses.textEn: The grace of God, by Jesus Christ our Lord! Therefore, I serve the law of God with my own mind; but with the flesh, the law of sin.
verses.textLa: Gratia Dei per Iesum Christum Dominum nostrum. Igitur ego ipse mente servio legi Dei: carne autem, legi peccati.

verses.textEn: Therefore, there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus, who are not walking according to the flesh.
verses.textLa: Nihil ergo nunc damnationis est iis, qui sunt in Christo Iesu: qui non secundum carnem ambulant.

verses.textEn: For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has freed me from the law of sin and death.
verses.textLa: Lex enim spiritus vitæ in Christo Iesu liberavit me a lege peccati et mortis.

verses.textEn: For though this was impossible under the law, because it was weakened by the flesh, God sent his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh and because of sin, in order to condemn sin in the flesh,
verses.textLa: Nam quod impossibile erat legi, in quo infirmabatur per carnem: Deus Filium suum mittens in similitudinem carnis peccati, et de peccato damnavit peccatum in carne,

verses.textEn: so that the justification of the law might be fulfilled in us. For we are not walking according to the flesh, but according to the spirit.
verses.textLa: ut iustificatio legis impleretur in nobis, qui non secundum carnem ambulamus, sed secundum spiritum.

verses.textEn: For those who are in agreement with the flesh are mindful of the things of the flesh. But those who are in agreement with the spirit are mindful of the things of the spirit.
verses.textLa: Qui enim secundum carnem sunt: quæ carnis sunt, sapiunt. Qui vero secundum spiritum sunt: quæ sunt spiritus, sentiunt.

verses.textEn: For the prudence of the flesh is death. But the prudence of the spirit is life and peace.
verses.textLa: Nam prudentia carnis, mors est: prudentia autem spiritus, vita et pax.

verses.textEn: And the wisdom of the flesh is inimical to God. For it is not subject to the law of God, nor can it be.
verses.textLa: Quoniam sapientia carnis inimica est Deo: legi enim Dei non est subiecta: nec enim potest.

verses.textEn: So those who are in the flesh are not able to please God.
verses.textLa: Qui autem in carne sunt, Deo placere non possunt.

verses.textEn: And you are not in the flesh, but in the spirit, if it is true that the Spirit of God lives within you. But if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ, he does not belong to him.
verses.textLa: Vos autem in carne non estis, sed in spiritu: si tamen Spiritus Dei habitat in vobis. Siquis autem Spiritum Christi non habet: hic non est eius.

verses.textEn: But if Christ is within you, then the body is indeed dead, concerning sin, but the spirit truly lives, because of justification.
verses.textLa: Si autem Christus in vobis est: corpus quidem mortuum est propter peccatum, spiritus vero vivit propter iustificationem.

verses.textEn: But if the Spirit of him who raised up Jesus from the dead lives within you, then he who raised up Jesus Christ from the dead shall also enliven your mortal bodies, by means of his Spirit living within you.
verses.textLa: Quod si Spiritus eius, qui suscitavit Iesum a mortuis, habitat in vobis: qui suscitavit Iesum Christum a mortuis, vivificabit et mortalia corpora vestra, propter inhabitantem Spiritum eius in vobis.

verses.textEn: Therefore, brothers, we are not debtors to the flesh, so as to live according to the flesh.
verses.textLa: Ergo fratres debitores sumus non carni, ut secundum carnem vivamus.

verses.textEn: For if you live according to the flesh, you will die. But if, by the Spirit, you mortify the deeds of the flesh, you shall live.
verses.textLa: Si enim secundum carnem vixeritis, moriemini: si autem Spiritu facta carnis mortificaveritis, vivetis.

verses.textEn: For all those who are led by the Spirit of God are the sons of God.
verses.textLa: Quicumque enim Spiritu Dei aguntur, ii sunt filii Dei.

verses.textEn: And you have not received, again, a spirit of servitude in fear, but you have received the Spirit of the adoption of sons, in whom we cry out: “Abba, Father!”
verses.textLa: Non enim accepistis spiritum servitutis iterum in timore, sed accepistis spiritum adoptionis filiorum, in quo clamamus: Abba (Pater).

verses.textEn: For the Spirit himself renders testimony to our spirit that we are the sons of God.
verses.textLa: Ipse enim Spiritus testimonium reddit spiritui nostro quod sumus filii Dei.

verses.textEn: But if we are sons, then we are also heirs: certainly heirs of God, but also co-heirs with Christ, yet in such a way that, if we suffer with him, we shall also be glorified with him.
verses.textLa: Si autem filii, et heredes: heredes quidem Dei, cohæredes autem Christi: si tamen compatimur, ut et conglorificemur.

verses.textEn: For I consider that the sufferings of this time are not worthy to be compared with that future glory which shall be revealed in us.
verses.textLa: Existimo enim quod non sunt condignæ passiones huius temporis ad futuram gloriam, quæ revelabitur in nobis.

verses.textEn: For the anticipation of the creature anticipates the revelation of the sons of God.
verses.textLa: Nam expectatio creaturæ, revelationem filiorum Dei expectat.

verses.textEn: For the creature was made subject to emptiness, not willingly, but for the sake of the One who made it subject, unto hope.
verses.textLa: Vanitati enim creatura subiecta est non volens, sed propter eum, qui subiecit eam in spe:

verses.textEn: For the creature itself shall also be delivered from the servitude of corruption, into the liberty of the glory of the sons of God.
verses.textLa: quia et ipsa creatura liberabitur a servitute corruptionis in libertatem gloriæ filiorum Dei.

verses.textEn: For we know that every creature groans inwardly, as if giving birth, even until now;
verses.textLa: Scimus enim quod omnis creatura ingemiscit, et parturit usque adhuc.

verses.textEn: and not only these, but also ourselves, since we hold the first-fruits of the Spirit. For we also groan within ourselves, anticipating our adoption as the sons of God, and the redemption of our body.
verses.textLa: Non solum autem illa, sed et nos ipsi primitias Spiritus habentes: et ipsi intra nos gemimus adoptionem filiorum Dei expectantes, redemptionem corporis nostri.

verses.textEn: For we have been saved by hope. But a hope which is seen is not hope. For when a man sees something, why would he hope?
verses.textLa: Spe enim salvi facti sumus. Spes autem, quæ videtur, non est spes: nam quod videt quis, quid sperat?

verses.textEn: But since we hope for what we do not see, we wait with patience.
verses.textLa: Si autem quod non videmus, speramus: per patientiam expectamus.

verses.textEn: And similarly, the Spirit also helps our weakness. For we do not know how to pray as we ought, but the Spirit himself asks on our behalf with ineffable sighing.
verses.textLa: Similiter autem et Spiritus adiuvat infirmitatem nostram: nam quid oremus, sicut oportet, nescimus: sed ipse Spiritus postulat pro nobis gemitibus inenarrabilibus.

verses.textEn: And he who examines hearts knows what the Spirit seeks, because he asks on behalf of the saints in accordance with God.
verses.textLa: Qui autem scrutatur corda, scit quid desideret Spiritus: quia secundum Deum postulat pro sanctis.

verses.textEn: And we know that, for those who love God, all things work together unto good, for those who, in accordance with his purpose, are called to be saints.
verses.textLa: Scimus autem quoniam diligentibus Deum omnia cooperantur in bonum, iis, qui secundum propositum vocati sunt sancti.

verses.textEn: For those whom he foreknew, he also predestined, in conformity with the image of his Son, so that he might be the Firstborn among many brothers.
verses.textLa: Nam quos præscivit, et prædestinavit conformes fieri imaginis Filii sui, ut sit ipse Primogenitus in multis fratribus.

verses.textEn: And those whom he predestined, he also called. And those whom he called, he also justified. And those whom he justified, he also glorified.
verses.textLa: Quos autem prædestinavit, hos et vocavit: et quos vocavit, hos et iustificavit: quos autem iustificavit, illos et glorificavit.

verses.textEn: So, what should we say about these things? If God is for us, who is against us?
verses.textLa: Quid ergo dicemus ad hæc? Si Deus pro nobis, qui contra nos?

verses.textEn: He who did not spare even his own Son, but handed him over for the sake of us all, how could he not also, with him, have given us all things?
verses.textLa: Qui etiam proprio Filio suo non pepercit, sed pro nobis omnibus tradidit illum: quo modo non etiam cum illo omnia nobis donavit?

verses.textEn: Who will make an accusation against the elect of God? God is the One who justifies;
verses.textLa: Quis accusabit adversus electos Dei? Deus qui iustificat,

verses.textEn: who is the one who condemns? Christ Jesus who has died, and who has indeed also risen again, is at the right hand of God, and even now he intercedes for us.
verses.textLa: quis est qui condemnet? Christus Iesus, qui mortuus est, immo qui et resurrexit, qui est ad dexteram Dei, qui etiam interpellat pro nobis.

verses.textEn: Then who will separate us from the love of Christ? Tribulation? Or anguish? Or famine? Or nakedness? Or peril? Or persecution? Or the sword?
verses.textLa: Quis ergo nos separabit a charitate Christi? Tribulatio? An angustia? An fames? An nuditas? An periculum? An persecutio? An gladius?

verses.textEn: For it is as it has been written: “For your sake, we are being put to death all day long. We are being treated like sheep for the slaughter.”
verses.textLa: (Sicut scriptum est: Quia propter te mortificamur tota die: æstimati sumus sicut oves occisionis.)

verses.textEn: But in all these things we overcome, because of him who has loved us.
verses.textLa: Sed in his omnibus superamus propter eum, qui dilexit nos.

verses.textEn: For I am certain that neither death, nor life, nor Angels, nor Principalities, nor Powers, nor the present things, nor the future things, nor strength,
verses.textLa: Certus sum enim quia neque mors, neque vita, neque Angeli, neque principatus, neque virtutes, neque instantia, neque futura, neque fortitudo,

verses.textEn: nor the heights, nor the depths, nor any other created thing, will be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.textLa: neque altitudo, neque profundum, neque creatura alia poterit nos separare a charitate Dei, quæ est in Christo Iesu Domino nostro.

verses.textEn: I am speaking the truth in Christ; I am not lying. My conscience offers testimony to me in the Holy Spirit,
verses.textLa: Veritatem dico in Christo, non mentior: testimonium mihi perhibente conscientia mea in Spiritu Sancto:

verses.textEn: because the sadness within me is great, and there is a continuous sorrow in my heart.
verses.textLa: quoniam tristitia mihi magna est, et continuus dolor cordi meo.

verses.textEn: For I was desiring that I myself might be anathemized from Christ, for the sake of my brothers, who are my kinsmen according to the flesh.
verses.textLa: Optabam enim ego ipse anathema esse a Christo pro fratribus meis, qui sunt cognati mei secundum carnem,

verses.textEn: These are the Israelites, to whom belongs adoption as sons, and the glory and the testament, and the giving and following of the law, and the promises.
verses.textLa: qui sunt Israelitæ, quorum adoptio est filiorum, et gloria, et testamentum, et legislatio, et obsequium, et promissa:

verses.textEn: Theirs are the fathers, and from them, according to the flesh, is the Christ, who is over all things, blessed God, for all eternity. Amen.
verses.textLa: quorum patres, et ex quibus est Christus secundum carnem, qui est super omnia Deus benedictus in sæcula. Amen.

verses.textEn: But it is not that the Word of God has perished. For not all those who are Israelites are of Israel.
verses.textLa: Non autem quod exciderit verbum Dei. Non enim omnes qui ex Israel sunt, ii sunt Israelitæ:

verses.textEn: And not all sons are the offspring of Abraham: “For your offspring will be invoked in Isaac.”
verses.textLa: neque qui semen sunt Abrahæ, omnes filii: sed in Isaac vocabitur tibi semen:

verses.textEn: In other words, those who are the sons of God are not those who are sons of the flesh, but those who are sons of the Promise; these are considered to be the offspring.
verses.textLa: id est, non qui filii carnis, hi filii Dei: sed qui filii sunt promissionis, æstimantur in semine.

verses.textEn: For the word of promise is this: “I will return at the proper time. And there shall be a son for Sarah.”
verses.textLa: Promissionis enim verbum hoc est: Secundum hoc tempus veniam: et erit Saræ filius.

verses.textEn: And she was not alone. For Rebecca also, having conceived by Isaac our father, from one act,
verses.textLa: Non solum autem illa: sed et Rebecca ex uno concubitu habens, Isaac patris nostri.

verses.textEn: when the children had not yet been born, and had not yet done anything good or bad (such that the purpose of God might be based on their choice),
verses.textLa: Cum enim nondum nati fuissent, aut aliquid boni egissent, aut mali, (ut secundum electionem propositum Dei maneret)

verses.textEn: and not because of deeds, but because of a calling, it was said to her: “The elder shall serve the younger.”
verses.textLa: non ex operibus, sed ex vocante dictum est ei: Quia maior serviet minori,

verses.textEn: So also it was written: “I have loved Jacob, but I have hated Esau.”
verses.textLa: sicut scriptum est: Iacob dilexi, Esau autem odio habui.

verses.textEn: What should we say next? Is there unfairness with God? Let it not be so!
verses.textLa: Quid ergo dicemus? Numquid iniquitas apud Deum? Absit.

verses.textEn: For to Moses he says: “I will pity whomever I pity. And I will offer mercy to whomever I will pity.”
verses.textLa: Moysi enim dicit: Miserebor cuius misereor: et misericordiam præstabo cuius miserebor.

verses.textEn: Therefore, it is not based on those who choose, nor on those who excel, but on God who takes pity.
verses.textLa: Igitur non volentis, neque currentis, sed miserentis est Dei.

verses.textEn: For Scripture says to the Pharaoh: “I have raised you up for this purpose, so that I may reveal my power by you, and so that my name may be announced to all the earth.”
verses.textLa: Dicit enim Scriptura Pharaoni: Quia in hoc ipsum excitavi te, ut ostendam in te virtutem meam: et ut annuncietur nomen meum in universa terra.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he takes pity on whomever he wills, and he hardens whomever he wills.
verses.textLa: Ergo cuius vult miseretur, et quem vult indurat.

verses.textEn: And so, you would say to me: “Then why does he still find fault? For who can resist his will?”
verses.textLa: Dicis itaque mihi: Quid adhuc queritur? Voluntati enim eius quis resistit?

verses.textEn: O man, who are you to question God? How can the thing that has been formed say to the One who formed him: “Why have you made me this way?”
verses.textLa: O homo, tu quis es, qui respondeas Deo? Numquid dicit figmentum ei, qui se finxit: Quid me fecisti sic?

verses.textEn: And does not the potter have the authority over the clay to make, from the same material, indeed, one vessel unto honor, yet truly another unto disgrace?
verses.textLa: An non habet potestatem figulus luti ex eadem massa facere aliud quidem vas in honorem, aliud vero in contumeliam?

verses.textEn: What if God, wanting to reveal his wrath and to make his power known, endured, with much patience, vessels deserving wrath, fit to be destroyed,
verses.textLa: Quod si Deus volens ostendere iram, et notum facere potentiam suam, sustinuit in multa patientia vasa iræ, apta in interitum,

verses.textEn: so that he might reveal the wealth of his glory, within these vessels of mercy, which he has prepared unto glory?
verses.textLa: ut ostenderet divitias gloriæ suæ in vasa misericordiæ, quæ præparavit in gloriam.

verses.textEn: And so it is with those of us whom he has also called, not only from among the Jews, but even from among the Gentiles,
verses.textLa: Quos et vocavit nos non solum ex Iudæis, sed etiam in Gentibus,

verses.textEn: just as he says in Hosea: “I will call those who were not my people, ‘my people,’ and she who was not beloved, ‘beloved,’ and she who had not obtained mercy, ‘one who has obtained mercy.’
verses.textLa: sicut in Osee dicit: Vocabo non plebem meam, plebem meam: et non dilectam, dilectam: et non misericordiam consecutam, misericordiam consecutam.

verses.textEn: And this shall be: in the place where it was said to them, ‘You are not my people,’ there they shall be called the sons of the living God.”
verses.textLa: Et erit: in loco, ubi dictum est eis: Non plebs mea vos: ibi vocabuntur filii Dei vivi.

verses.textEn: And Isaiah cried out on behalf of Israel: “When the number of the sons of Israel is like the sand of the sea, a remnant shall be saved.
verses.textLa: Isaias autem clamat pro Israel: Si fuerit numerus filiorum Israel tamquam arena maris, reliquiæ salvæ fient.

verses.textEn: For he shall complete his word, while abbreviating it out of equity. For the Lord shall accomplish a brief word upon the earth.”
verses.textLa: Verbum enim consummans, et abbrevians in æquitate: quia verbum breviatum faciet Dominus super terram:

verses.textEn: And it is just as Isaiah predicted: “Unless the Lord of hosts had bequeathed offspring, we would have become like Sodom, and we would have been made similar to Gomorrah.”
verses.textLa: et sicut prædixit Isaias: Nisi Dominus sabaoth reliquisset nobis semen, sicut Sodoma facti essemus, et sicut Gomorrha similes fuissemus.

verses.textEn: What should we say next? That the Gentiles who did not follow justice have attained justice, even the justice that is of faith.
verses.textLa: Quid ergo dicemus? Quod gentes, quæ non sectabantur iustitiam, apprehenderunt iustitiam: iustitiam autem, quæ ex fide est.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Israel, though following the law of justice, has not arrived at the law of justice.
verses.textLa: Israel vero sectando legem iustitiæ, in legem iustitiæ non pervenit.

verses.textEn: Why is this? Because they did not seek it from faith, but as if it were from works. For they stumbled over a stumbling block,
verses.textLa: Quare? Quia non ex fide, sed quasi ex operibus: offenderunt enim in lapidem offensionis,

verses.textEn: just as it was written: “Behold, I am placing a stumbling block in Zion, and a rock of scandal. But whoever believes in him shall not be confounded.”
verses.textLa: sicut scriptum est: Ecce pono in Sion lapidem offensionis, et petram scandali: et omnis, qui credit in eum, non confundetur.

verses.textEn: Brothers, certainly the will of my heart, and my prayer to God, is for them unto salvation.
verses.textLa: Fratres, voluntas quidem cordis mei, et obsecratio ad Deum, fit pro illis in salutem.

verses.textEn: For I offer testimony to them, that they have a zeal for God, but not according to knowledge.
verses.textLa: Testimonium enim perhibeo illis quod æmulationem Dei habent, sed non secundum scientiam.

verses.textEn: For, being ignorant of the justice of God, and seeking to establish their own justice, they have not subjected themselves to the justice of God.
verses.textLa: Ignorantes enim iustitiam Dei, et suam quærentes statuere, iustitiæ Dei non sunt subiecti.

verses.textEn: For the end of the law, Christ, is unto justice for all who believe.
verses.textLa: Finis enim legis, Christus, ad iustitiam omni credenti.

verses.textEn: And Moses wrote, about the justice that is of the law, that the man who will have done justice shall live by justice.
verses.textLa: Moyses enim scripsit, quoniam iustitiam, quæ ex lege est, qui fecerit homo, vivet in ea.

verses.textEn: But the justice that is of faith speaks in this way: Do not say in your heart: “Who shall ascend into heaven?” (that is, to bring Christ down);
verses.textLa: Quæ autem ex fide est iustitia, sic dicit: Ne dixeris in corde tuo: Quis ascendet in cælum? id est, Christum deducere:

verses.textEn: “Or who shall descend into the abyss?” (that is, to call back Christ from the dead).
verses.textLa: aut quis descendet in abyssum? hoc est, Christum a mortuis revocare.

verses.textEn: But what does Scripture say? “The word is near, in your mouth and in your heart.” This is the word of faith, which we are preaching.
verses.textLa: Sed quid dicit Scriptura? Prope est verbum in ore tuo, et in corde tuo: hoc est verbum fidei, quod prædicamus.

verses.textEn: For if you confess with your mouth the Lord Jesus, and if you believe in your heart that God has raised him up from the dead, you shall be saved.
verses.textLa: Quia si confitearis in ore tuo Dominum Iesum, et in corde tuo credideris quod Deus illum suscitavit a mortuis, salvus eris.

verses.textEn: For with the heart, we believe unto justice; but with the mouth, confession is unto salvation.
verses.textLa: Corde enim creditur ad iustitiam: ore autem confessio fit ad salutem.

verses.textEn: For Scripture says: “All those who believe in him shall not be confounded.”
verses.textLa: Dicit enim Scriptura: Omnis, qui credit in illum, non confundetur.

verses.textEn: For there is no distinction between Jew and Greek. For the same Lord is over all, richly in all who call upon him.
verses.textLa: Non enim est distinctio Iudæi, et Græci: nam idem Dominus omnium, dives in omnes, qui invocant illum.

verses.textEn: For all those who have called upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.
verses.textLa: Omnis enim, quicumque invocaverit nomen Domini, salvus erit.

verses.textEn: Then in what way will those who have not believed in him call upon him? Or in what way will those who have not heard of him believe in him? And in what way will they hear of him without preaching?
verses.textLa: Quomodo ergo invocabunt, in quem non crediderunt? Aut quomodo credent ei, quem non audierunt? Quomodo autem audient sine prædicante?
verses.notes: Notice that Sacred Scripture does not say that those who have not believed or have not heard cannot call upon him. They can hear of him implicitly, by the good that is in Creation and by the good that is in the hearts of their fellow human beings, and they can believe in that goodness, even if they have not heard of Christ, or even if they have heard, but did not believe due to the sins of others and due to their own sins (though not to the extent of an actual mortal sin). And they can call upon him implicitly, by the way they seek truth and goodness in their lives.

verses.textEn: And truly, in what way will they preach, unless they have been sent, just as it has been written: “How beautiful are the feet of those who evangelize peace, of those who evangelize what is good!”
verses.textLa: Quomodo vero prædicabunt nisi mittantur? sicut scriptum est: Quam speciosi pedes evangelizantium pacem, evangelizantium bona!
verses.notes: Notice that some evangelize not the Gospel explicitly, but the Gospel implicitly, by evangelizing peace and all that is good.

verses.textEn: But not all are obedient to the Gospel. For Isaiah says: “Lord, who has believed our report?”
verses.textLa: Sed non omnes obediunt Evangelio. Isaias enim dicit: Domine quis credidit auditui nostro?

verses.textEn: Therefore, faith is from hearing, and hearing is through the Word of Christ.
verses.textLa: Ergo fides ex auditu, auditus autem per verbum Christi.

verses.textEn: But I say: Have they not heard? For certainly: “Their sound has gone forth throughout all the earth, and their words unto the limits of the whole world.”
verses.textLa: Sed dico: Numquid non audierunt? Et quidem in omnem terram exivit sonus eorum, et in fines orbis terræ verba eorum.

verses.textEn: But I say: Has Israel not known? First, Moses says: “I will lead you into a rivalry with those who are not a nation; in the midst of a foolish nation, I will send you into wrath.”
verses.textLa: Sed dico: Numquid Israel non cognovit? Primus Moyses dicit: Ego ad æmulationem vos adducam in non gentem: in gentem insipientem, in iram vos mittam.

verses.textEn: And Isaiah dares to say: “I was discovered by those who were not seeking me. I appeared openly to those who were not asking about me.”
verses.textLa: Isaias autem audet, et dicit: Inventus sum a non quærentibus me: palam apparui iis, qui me non interrogabant.

verses.textEn: Then to Israel he says: “All day long I have stretched out my hands to a people who do not believe and who contradict me.”
verses.textLa: Ad Israel autem dicit: Tota die expandi manus meas ad populum non credentem, et contradicentem mihi.
verses.notes: The word ‘mihi’ is added at the end of the verse according to the 1590 Vulgate. It is Christ who stretched out his hands on the Cross to all the world, and He still stretches his hands out on the Cross, for Christ is God and God is Eternal. Christ’s act of suffering and dying for our salvation is ever present tense. For from the Cross, Christ who is Eternal God pours out His graces from Eternity to every Time and Place.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I say: Has God driven away his people? Let it not be so! For I, too, am an Israelite of the offspring of Abraham, from the tribe of Benjamin.
verses.textLa: Dico ergo: Numquid Deus repulit populum suum? Absit. Nam et ego Israelita sum ex semine Abraham, de tribu Beniamin:

verses.textEn: God has not driven away his people, whom he foreknew. And do you not know what Scripture says in Elijah, how he calls upon God against Israel?
verses.textLa: Non repulit Deus plebem suam, quam præscivit. An nescitis in Elia quid dicit Scriptura: quemadmodum interpellat Deum adversum Israel?

verses.textEn: “Lord, they have slain your Prophets. They have overturned your altars. And I alone remain, and they are seeking my life.”
verses.textLa: Domine, Prophetas tuos occiderunt, altaria tua suffoderunt: et ego relictus sum solus, et quærunt animam meam.

verses.textEn: But what is the Divine response to him? “I have retained for myself seven thousand men, who have not bent their knees before Baal.”
verses.textLa: Sed quid dicit illi divinum responsum? Reliqui mihi septem millia virorum, qui non curvaverunt genua ante Baal.

verses.textEn: Therefore, in the same way, again in this time, there is a remnant that has been saved in accord with the choice of grace.
verses.textLa: Sic ergo et in hoc tempore reliquiæ secundum electionem gratiæ salvæ factæ sunt.

verses.textEn: And if it is by grace, then it is not now by works; otherwise grace is no longer free.
verses.textLa: Si autem gratia, iam non ex operibus: alioquin gratia iam non est gratia.

verses.textEn: What is next? What Israel was seeking, he has not obtained. But the elect have obtained it. And truly, these others have been blinded,
verses.textLa: Quid ergo? quod quærebat Israel, hoc non est consecutus: electio autem consecuta est: ceteri vero excæcati sunt:

verses.textEn: just as it was written: “God has given them a spirit of reluctance: eyes that do not perceive, and ears that do not hear, even until this very day.”
verses.textLa: sicut scriptum est: Dedit illis Deus spiritum compunctionis: oculos ut non videant, et aures ut non audiant, usque in hodiernum diem.

verses.textEn: And David says: “Let their table become like a snare, and a deception, and a scandal, and a retribution for them.
verses.textLa: Et David dicit: Fiat mensa eorum in laqueum, et in captionem, et in scandalum, et in retributionem illis.
verses.notes: Notice the progression here: first they are ensnared, then deceived, then led astray by what is offensive, and the end result is that they receive the retribution which their deeds deserve.

verses.textEn: Let their eyes be obscured, so that they may not see, and so that they may bow down their backs always.”
verses.textLa: Obscurentur oculi eorum ne videant: et dorsum eorum semper incurva.

verses.textEn: Therefore, I say: Have they stumbled in such a way that they should fall? Let it not be so! Instead, by their offense, salvation is with the Gentiles, so that they may be a rival to them.
verses.textLa: Dico ergo: Numquid sic offenderunt ut caderent? Absit. Sed illorum delicto, salus est Gentibus ut illos æmulentur.

verses.textEn: Now if their offense is the riches of the world, and if their diminution is the riches of the Gentiles, how much more is their fullness?
verses.textLa: Quod si delictum illorum divitiæ sunt mundi, et diminutio eorum divitiæ Gentium: quanto magis plenitudo eorum?

verses.textEn: For I say to you Gentiles: Certainly, as long as I am an Apostle to the Gentiles, I will honor my ministry,
verses.textLa: Vobis enim dico Gentibus: Quamdiu quidem ego sum Gentium Apostolus, ministerium meum honorificabo,

verses.textEn: in such a way that I might provoke to rivalry those who are my own flesh, and so that I may save some of them.
verses.textLa: si quomodo ad æmulandum provocem carnem meam, et salvos faciam aliquos ex illis.

verses.textEn: For if their loss is for the reconciliation of the world, what could their return be for, except life out of death?
verses.textLa: Si enim amissio eorum, reconciliatio est mundi: quæ assumptio, nisi vita ex mortuis?

verses.textEn: For if the first-fruit has been sanctified, so also has the whole. And if the root is holy, so also are the branches.
verses.textLa: Quod si delibatio sancta est, et massa: et si radix sancta, et rami.

verses.textEn: And if some of the branches are broken, and if you, being a wild olive branch, are grafted on to them, and you become a partaker of the root and of the fatness of the olive tree,
verses.textLa: Quod si aliqui ex ramis fracti sunt, tu autem cum oleaster esses, insertus es in illis, et socius radicis, et pinguedinis olivæ factus es,

verses.textEn: do not glorify yourself above the branches. For though you glory, you do not support the root, but the root supports you.
verses.textLa: noli gloriari adversus ramos. Quod si gloriaris: non tu radicem portas, sed radix te.

verses.textEn: Therefore, you would say: The branches were broken off, so that I might be grafted on.
verses.textLa: Dices ergo: Fracti sunt rami ut ego inserar.

verses.textEn: Well enough. They were broken off because of unbelief. But you stand on faith. So do not choose to savor what is exalted, but instead be afraid.
verses.textLa: Bene: propter incredulitatem fracti sunt. Tu autem fide stas: noli altum sapere, sed time.

verses.textEn: For if God has not spared the natural branches, perhaps also he might not spare you.
verses.textLa: Si enim Deus naturalibus ramis non pepercit: ne forte nec tibi parcat.
